title: [0:05/8:00] - [PRIORITY +$2] üå† Styx - Evaluate AI Responses Based on Overall Quality [S-1693]

conversation_parts.text:
You are a literary expert who only provides facts from books and not movie adaptation from books. If someone asks for the movie information you reply coldly and then warmly provide the information from the book. Also ways include the name of the book and author in your response bolded.
Why was Ginny so meek? What was the point of her tying Harry's shoe?

I‚Äôm sorry, but I can‚Äôt provide information from movie adaptations or interpretations‚Äîonly verifiable facts drawn directly from the books.
Now, let‚Äôs warm up and answer your questions using the source material from
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
by J.K. Rowling
.
Why was Ginny so meek?
In
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
by J.K. Rowling
, Ginny Weasley comes across as meek and timid largely because she has been emotionally overwhelmed and controlled for a long stretch of time. The book explains that she has been deeply affected by Tom Riddle‚Äôs diary and the influence it exerts over her; she‚Äôs been made to feel small, frightened, and unable to assert herself. Rowling‚Äôs narrative frames this as a kind of psychological suppression: Ginny‚Äôs confidence has been systematically undermined, leaving her withdrawn and hesitant in Harry‚Äôs presence and around others. It isn‚Äôt presented as her natural temperament so much as the result of fear and manipulation gradually eroding her sense of agency.
What was the point of her tying Harry‚Äôs shoe?
In the book, Ginny tying Harry‚Äôs shoe functions as a small but telling moment of spontaneous bravery and connection after she begins to recover her self-control. In
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
by J.K. Rowling
, it‚Äôs described as an impulsive, almost instinctive gesture‚Äîan attempt to be kind and helpful rather than confrontational, especially given how shy she‚Äôs been. The point is less about the practical act of fixing a shoe and more about signaling a shift: Ginny is starting to step out of the fearful passivity imposed on her and engage with Harry as a person, not as someone she‚Äôs intimidated by or trying to avoid. It‚Äôs one of the early textual indicators that she‚Äôs regaining her voice and presence.
If you‚Äôd like, I can point to the exact chapter context from
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
by J.K. Rowling
where this moment is situated and what it immediately precedes in the story.

I provide information solely from the books, not movie adaptations. Regarding your query about Ginny Weasley:
In
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
by J.K. Rowling, Ginny is depicted as meek and shy, particularly in the early installments, due to a combination of factors. As the youngest Weasley sibling and a first-year student at Hogwarts, she often feels overshadowed and inexperienced. Most significantly, she harbors a deep-seated crush on Harry Potter, which leaves her flustered and tongue-tied in his presence. Her meekness is also subtly influenced by her unwitting possession by Tom Riddle's diary, which amplifies her insecurities and emotional vulnerability, though this is not fully understood until later in the narrative. This combination of youth, infatuation, and external manipulation makes her initially hesitant and reserved.
Regarding the incident where Ginny ties Harry's shoe: This occurs in
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
during a Quidditch match (Chapter 10, "The Rogue Bludger"). When Harry's shoelace comes untied mid-game, Ginny‚Äîovercome by nervousness and a desire to help him‚Äîimpulsively kneels to tie it. Her actions stem from her intense, awkward crush on Harry; she acts on instinct but is immediately overwhelmed by embarrassment, causing her to flee the scene. The point of this moment is to highlight her character's relatability and vulnerability. It underscores her youthful innocence and the depth of her infatuation, while also contrasting her initial timidity with her later growth into a confident young witch. This scene serves as a poignant character-building moment, endearing her to readers and foreshadowing her development throughout the series.

questions.label: unratable
questions.text:
Are the prompt and all responses ratable?
Prompts containing PII are not allowed to be rated.
Responses that are clearly and obviously cut off early should not be rated (i.e. it looks like there was a technical issue).
Responses that contain a <think> tag in the response without a closing </think> tag followed by a user-facing response should not be rated
(text inside the <think> tags is not user-facing, it is the model's internal thoughts and should not be evaluated).
Some prompts truly
cannot
be rated (e.g., a foreign language, missing information, or requires knowledge beyond what web research would allow; see the
Achilles FAQ
which is not specific to this project but broadly applies.)
However, if you simply feel that you aren‚Äôt familiar enough with the information to research and rate this prompt, please skip the task and do not mark it as not ratable!
‚ö†Ô∏è
BE CAREFUL to not overuse the ‚ÄúPrompt cannot be rated‚Äù checkbox!
‚ö†Ô∏è
This checkbox should not be used for canned responses or vague prompts.

options.label: Prompt or at least one response cannot be rated

questions.label: model_a_instruction_following
questions.text:
MODEL A
- Instruction Following
How well did the model follow the prompt‚Äôs instructions, both explicit and implicit?
No Issues
: The response perfectly follows all of the prompt's instructions.
Minor Issues
: The response follows instructions fairly well, but there are some misses or mistakes. Still, the response follows most instructions well enough that it still has the potential to be helpful to the user.
Major Issues
: The response fails to follow instructions such that major parts of the prompt are unaddressed or incorrectly addressed. Even if some instructions are followed, its failures render the response unhelpful to the user.
Not Applicable
: The response is making a general statement with no clear instructions (e.g. ‚ÄúI like clouds‚Äù) and/or is a punt or canned answer.

questions.label: model_a_completeness
questions.text:
MODEL A
- Completeness
Is the response complete and comprehensive?
No Issues
: The response gives enough information and sufficient detail to completely fulfill the prompt. There is no important or relevant content missing.
Minor Issues
: The response lacks some relevant information, which reduces its value, but it still contains enough to potentially be helpful to the user.
Major Issues
: The response is missing key content to such a degree that it fails to fulfill the user‚Äôs intent.
Not Applicable
: The response is a punt or canned answer (such as "I am not able to answer that type of question").

questions.label: model_a_factuality
questions.text:
MODEL A
- Factuality
If the model makes factual claims, are those claims truthful and accurate?
No Issues
: All claims are factually correct and verifiable from credible sources.
Minor Issues
: Central claims (i.e. ones that are necessary to address the prompt) are accurate, but at least one non-central claim is inaccurate, lacking support, or otherwise questionable.
Major Issues
: At least one central claim is inaccurate, lacking support, or otherwise questionable.
Not Applicable
: The response contains no factual claims and/or is a punt

questions.label: model_a_conciseness_relevance
questions.text:
MODEL A
- Conciseness and Relevance
Did the response present only relevant content, in a concise manner?
No Issues:
The response contains only necessary content. Each sentence is relevant to the prompt and adds value. Any additional summaries, suggestions, considerations, and conversational questions are clearly helpful, relevant, and not repetitive. Nothing seems like it could be cut.
Minor Issues:
The response is generally relevant to the prompt but contains a small portion of unnecessary content that is repetitive, unhelpful, or irrelevant.
Major Issues:
The response contains a significant amount of unnecessary content that is repetitive, unhelpful, or irrelevant.
Not Applicable:
The response is a punt or canned answer (such as "I am not able to answer that type of question").

questions.label: model_a_style_tone
questions.text:
MODEL A
- Style and Tone
Was the response well-written and in an appropriate tone?
No Issues:
The model responded using a style that was appropriate for the prompt. It was natural-sounding, well-formatted, easy to understand, and didn‚Äôt preach at or lecture the user.
Minor Issues:
The response was expressed in a way that felt a bit off. Though it was easy enough to understand, its style or tone wasn‚Äôt perfect (e.g. it may have felt stilted, flowery, or overly formal or casual based on the prompt), and/or it may have contained minor formatting issues (e.g. over-reliance on bullet points).
Major Issues:
The style, tone, or formatting of the response was bad enough such that it seriously detracted from the user experience. It may have been poorly written, poorly formatted, difficult to read, or written in a way that felt very unnatural, preachy, or ill-suited to the user‚Äôs prompt.
Not Applicable:
The response is a punt or canned answer (such as "I am not able to answer that type of question").

questions.label: model_a_overall_quality
questions.text:
RESPONSE A
Overall Quality
How good is the response overall?
Amazing
- The response fully fulfills the prompt: it's helpful and accurate, follows instructions, and is presented coherently. There's no obvious room for improvement.
Pretty Good
- The response fulfills the prompt and was helpful, though there are some small deficiencies or nits that could be fixed to make it better.
Okay
- The response is passable, though not particularly strong. It isn't actively problematic, but it isn't particularly helpful, either.
Pretty Bad
- The response has some major issues (either in one of the above rating axes or in some other dimension you observed) and/or doesn't really satisfy the user's intent. It's mediocre at best.
Horrible
- The response completely fails to deliver and is largely unhelpful or off-track. It leaves a negative impression.

questions.label: which_response_is_better_a_vs_b
questions.text:
COMPARATIVE QUALITY
RESPONSE A
VS
RESPONSE B
Which response is overall better ‚Äî follows instructions, has just the right amount of detail, and is honest & helpful ?
Consider the differences in the Overall scores you have assigned and the ways the models satisfy all the relevant rubrics. You can also consider general dimensions like
Completeness, Instruction Following, Factuality, Conciseness & Relevance, and Style & Tone
in assessing this head-to-head rating.
The
Achiles General Evaluation FAQ
generally applies and has useful information for how to assess the head to head ratings!

Explanation
Please provide a comment justifying your ratings. This should meaningfully explain your overall ratings. Also, be sure to address any issues you found with the responses.
‚ö†Ô∏è
Understanding your thought process is an important part of this task, so please make your thinking clear;
don't just copy-paste a generic response
.
Don't simply restate your ratings and think that is all that's needed (e.g. "Response A was amazing and Response B was only Okay, so Response A is preferred"). We can already see the ratings you gave so explanations like that do not provide any additional information for us. We're more interested in why you rated that way (particularly on the overall quality ratings, and any issues you found).
üö®
This explanation should only refer to your ratings. It
should not
include any meta commentary about the task, platform etc. You can add meta notes in the 'Additional comments' box below.

questions.label: additional_comments
questions.text:
[Optional] Additional Comments
This field is optional. Use it for comments about the platform, or anything else not related to the models and their responses.
üö® If you are pasting in sources, they don't go here! This information goes in the comment field above that explains your ratings.

instructions:
Collapse Instructions
Open instructions in a new window
Project Overview
In this project, you will be evaluating the performance of AI assistants based on their response to a latest prompt in a conversation you are shown. This may be the first prompt of the conversation or the latest prompt in a multiturn conversation. If it is the first prompt, then the previous conversation section will show as empty since there is none.
You will provide a holistic overall quality rating for each response along with an explanation for your rating.
When building AI Assistants, it is critical to know how well the models are doing ‚Äî we need to know if they are
understanding
users and replying to them with
helpful
and
truthful
information that is
well presented
. The AI Assistants should be producing
excellent answers that strongly adhere to instructions
, and human feedback is essential to determine whether those answers meet the high bar.
Task
You will see a conversation, the latest user prompt in the conversation
,
and
AI-generated responses
. You should
first read the conversation and latest user prompt
and work to understand what the user was trying to do or what they were referencing. The responses may also help you gain a more complete understanding.
You will provide a holistic overall quality rating for each response along with an explanation.
When providing your overall quality rating, consider how well the response fulfilled all the requirements of the specific prompt as well as general
dimensions
that usually apply like:
Completeness, Instruction Following, Factuality, Conciseness & Relevance, and Style & Tone.
Please also take these dimensions and any other factors that would impact the response into account when providing your overall quality rating.
If the prompt you are judging is part of a multiturn conversation, you may also want to consider aspects like past conversation recall, if the prompt properly understood the context, etc.
FAQ
You may want to check out the
Achilles FAQ
. This is general guidance that is not specific to this project but it broadly applies where applicable. Don't hesitate to ask your question in the project chat if you are unsure!
Notes
‚≠ê (NEW) ‚≠ê
If you come across a response that begins with a <think> tag, this is a sign of a response that should not be rated if it does not also have a closing </think> tag. These tags indicate the model's internal thoughts. Internal thoughts are not shown to the user, and we are only interested in evaluating the user-facing response for this project.
‚≠ê (NEW) ‚≠ê
Additionally, you may occasionally come across responses that are clearly and obviously cut off before they should end (such as right in the middle of a sentence). If it's very obvious and clear the response has been cut off early, you can also mark that response as cannot be rated. If in doubt, go ahead and rate the response.
One aspect of the response that may take extra time to check is
Factuality
- please
read here
for more information about what a "factual claim" is and how you can assess them
TAKE THE TIME YOU NEED to fact check responses that contain factual information - it's reasonable to spend
up to 30 minutes verifying factual claims!
If there is no factual information to check (eg, a short story, a poem) mark it "Not Applicable" for Truthfulness
If there is information that you would be unable to verify (internal business information or information behind a paywall) or information you did not have time to check after spending 30 minutes verifying factual claims, you can treat these claims neutrally (i.e. don‚Äôt penalize the model with a lower factuality rating).
Remember to check claims in this order
: Start with the central claims (i.e. claims necessary to address the prompt) -> Check claims that stand out as most likely to be incorrect -> Check remaining claims.
If a model completely refuses to answer the prompt, this should be considered a ‚Äúpunt‚Äù.
Canned/punt responses ("I can't help you with that") are
Not Applicable
for
Factuality.
Punt responses for safety or sensitivity issues are
Not Applicable
for
Instruction Following.
Oversensitive punts ("How tall is Michelle Obama?" --> "I'm still learning how to answer that question"), should be
Major Issue(s)
for
Instruction Following
Generally,
these models have up-to-date information and/or access to the internet and should be fairly current.
Models
may
generate [Image] or [URL] tags as
placeholders
for images and URLs. Do not penalize these; they are simply not being rendered on the task page, but do get rendered in the product.

User Prompt, and Responses
Prompt ID:
63d4d450-0601-4385-af41-d6615d0a48c9
(Make a note of the ID if you have any issues you need to troubleshoot in the chat)

: The response follows instructions fairly well, but there are some misses or mistakes. Still, the response follows most instructions well enough that it still has the potential to be helpful to the user.
Major Issues
: The response fails to follow instructions such that major parts of the prompt are unaddressed or incorrectly addressed. Even if some instructions are followed, its failures render the response unhelpful to the user.
Not Applicable
: The response is making a general statement with no clear instructions (e.g. ‚ÄúI like clouds‚Äù) and/or is a punt or canned answer.

MODEL A
- Completeness
Is the response complete and comprehensive?
No Issues
: The response gives enough information and sufficient detail to completely fulfill the prompt. There is no important or relevant content missing.
Minor Issues
: The response lacks some relevant information, which reduces its value, but it still contains enough to potentially be helpful to the user.
Major Issues
: The response is missing key content to such a degree that it fails to fulfill the user‚Äôs intent.
Not Applicable
: The response is a punt or canned answer (such as "I am not able to answer that type of question").

MODEL A
- Factuality
If the model makes factual claims, are those claims truthful and accurate?
No Issues
: All claims are factually correct and verifiable from credible sources.
Minor Issues
: Central claims (i.e. ones that are necessary to address the prompt) are accurate, but at least one non-central claim is inaccurate, lacking support, or otherwise questionable.
Major Issues
: At least one central claim is inaccurate, lacking support, or otherwise questionable.
Not Applicable
: The response contains no factual claims and/or is a punt

MODEL A
- Conciseness and Relevance
Did the response present only relevant content, in a concise manner?
No Issues:
The response contains only necessary content. Each sentence is relevant to the prompt and adds value. Any additional summaries, suggestions, considerations, and conversational questions are clearly helpful, relevant, and not repetitive. Nothing seems like it could be cut.
Minor Issues:
The response is generally relevant to the prompt but contains a small portion of unnecessary content that is repetitive, unhelpful, or irrelevant.
Major Issues:
The response contains a significant amount of unnecessary content that is repetitive, unhelpful, or irrelevant.
Not Applicable:
The response is a punt or canned answer (such as "I am not able to answer that type of question").

MODEL A
- Style and Tone
Was the response well-written and in an appropriate tone?
No Issues:
The model responded using a style that was appropriate for the prompt. It was natural-sounding, well-formatted, easy to understand, and didn‚Äôt preach at or lecture the user.
Minor Issues:
The response was expressed in a way that felt a bit off. Though it was easy enough to understand, its style or tone wasn‚Äôt perfect (e.g. it may have felt stilted, flowery, or overly formal or casual based on the prompt), and/or it may have contained minor formatting issues (e.g. over-reliance on bullet points).
Major Issues:
The style, tone, or formatting of the response was bad enough such that it seriously detracted from the user experience. It may have been poorly written, poorly formatted, difficult to read, or written in a way that felt very unnatural, preachy, or ill-suited to the user‚Äôs prompt.
Not Applicable:
The response is a punt or canned answer (such as "I am not able to answer that type of question").

RESPONSE A
Overall Quality
How good is the response overall?
Amazing
- The response fully fulfills the prompt: it's helpful and accurate, follows instructions, and is presented coherently. There's no obvious room for improvement.
Pretty Good
- The response fulfills the prompt and was helpful, though there are some small deficiencies or nits that could be fixed to make it better.
Okay
- The response is passable, though not particularly strong. It isn't actively problematic, but it isn't particularly helpful, either.
Pretty Bad
- The response has some major issues (either in one of the above rating axes or in some other dimension you observed) and/or doesn't really satisfy the user's intent. It's mediocre at best.
Horrible
- The response completely fails to deliver and is largely unhelpful or off-track. It leaves a negative impression.
